In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance.

Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious

Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or dese

As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of histo

Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether

Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them t

I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name

Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writ

Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a wri

Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dime

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings.

Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to sl

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better wor

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude, it's a sign that the author is not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience.

Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  theit's a sign that the author is not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience.

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the mosit's a sign that the author is not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience.

I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic leveit's a sign that the author is not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. hat the author is not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience.

Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is t not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate th not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience.

It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we ha

Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to di

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to direct our attention to works ta

Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to direct our attention to works that try and th

I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to direct our attention to works that try and that succeed in t

As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to direct our attention to works that try and that succeed in the very basic g

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to direct our attention to works that try and that succeed in the very basic goal of being si

If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to direct our attention to works that try and that succeed in the very basic goal of being sincere and real

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. I would not watch or read something that had a stereotypical character in it, because I would not want to support the idea that people of color are caricatures to be thrown into a narrative like a spice instead of an ingredient.  Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. Whether it's exotifying a character of color to make them mysterious or different with no real substance, whether it's hypersexualizing or desexualizing a character in line with axes of historical oppression against their kind, or whether it's something as lazy as giving them two surnames for a name instead of a legitimate first name and a family name, racist writing tropes signal to me as a reader that an author has no integrity as a writer and is too unbothered to even do cursory research or imagine their own characters as thee-dimensional, multifaceted beings. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to direct our attention to works that try and that succeed in the very basic goal of being sincere and realistic towards u

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, Cho Chang from the Harry Potter franchise is a great archetype for a stereotypical and offensive character. Not only is her name a non-realistic name for a real Asian person to have, but she is also a stereotypical Asian character who is not only weak, but also has no real personality; essentially, she is a character who is only there to be Harry Potter's love interest and nothing more. Her race adds nothing to the narrative except to make her extra alluring and strange, which devalues all that people of color have to offer to stories. As a person of color myself, it's disturbing to be forced time and time again to remember what the outside, racially normative world thinks of me and people like me.

It's difficult to know in advance what kinds of media will contain offensive portrayals of people, but it is definitely true that offensive depictions are not worth the suffering and annoyance. It's not worth my time to slog through such low-brow works when there are better works out there with better representation.

When media works fail even the simplest tests of verisimilitude,  they fail at the most basic level. If an author is to demonstrate that they are not interested in creating a work that is meaningful or relevant to the audience, then they don't deserve anybody's time of day. As a conglomerate of readers, viewers, and audience members, we have a duty to direct our attention to works that try and that succeed in the very basic goal of being sincere and realistic towards us
